comments.commentBody: It's too late to pull back for the Republicans. They're already on record voting to kill Medicare and it will get lots of air play next year.
Perhaps they finally glanced at the polls where anywhere between 63% and 80% of the citizens don't want Ryans plan.

The Republicans showed their hole cards. The notion that retired people with health issues (and who doesn't have some) can buy health coverage for 15k is absurd. And if they don't have the money in the bank to cover the shortfall, where will they get health care? They will mortgage their home to pay for doctor or hospital visits, but that money won't last long. And if they lose the home and move in with their kids, what then? Will the kids mortgage THEIR home to scrape up money for Dad's bypass surgery or Mom's breast cancer treatments? Will the kids lose their home, too. Even if they died at home, there would be money for pain medication. What a nightmare, multiplied by 50 million baby boomers and their kids. God!
Congratulations.  Maybe congratulations twice.  Good luck.

I agree that his comments should not disqualify him from receiving an honorary degree from John Jay, but query where all of you were when Michael Oren, Israeli Ambassador to the US and a world-reknowned academic, was subject to campaigns seeking to bar him from speaking at Brandeis University lasy June.  I get the feeling that a fair amount of this derives from hositlity to Israel and not support for freedom of speech.
Why is CUNY, a publicly funded institution, giving honorary degrees to nonscholars in the first place?
Only in New York...

It would be great if this incident caused us to look more closely at some of the individuals on that board.  It would be an understatement to say that they are, with few exceptions, an unimpressive lot, and example of New York's sad addiction to patronage and political correctness.  Time to clean it out.

Does the fact that one of the trustees, by her own and curiously candid admission, had never even heard of Mr. Kushner, tell us something about the University's academic standards?
An interesting reflection, perhaps, on our much-assaulted public education system. In which case, Mr, Kushner might not be particularly interested in being so dishonored by that honorable degree.
Sepaking of appropriate credentials for honorary awards....let's have a serious conversation about the Nobel Peace Prize...

First in response to a comment, Mr. Kushner's viewpoints are not racist. You may agree or disagree with his views but avoid the rhetoric. Second, it is not quite analogous to tenure as this is an honorary degree. But it is a step down the road, and clearly, for that reason, the trustees should resign, all of the trustees, as the trustees were not clearly aware of the role of a public university to promote free speech. Imagine a university where only the strong advocates of Zionism could make their views known. Would Israel be any safer with such a one-sided discourse?

Hardly.

So here we are, 6 May, another Friday with a full weekend ahead and no Playstation Network. It is truly a shame whoever participated in hacking over 77+ million peoples entertainment network. Did you focus on a bank? A stock broker firm? No, you took something away from the average person's means of having some happiness and fun while they're not busting hump during this terrible economy. Honesty, you (hackers) should be ashamed of such a target.

I own both a PS3 and Xbox(360), and also several PC games. To be frank, IMHO PC games blow away both consoles, at least for high-end PC's. My sound card alone costs as much as an Xbox. But, my PC cannot play Guitar Hero. My 3rd absolute favorite online game behind a couple unnamed but well know MMORPGs. While I think Activision pulled the plug on GH series way too soon, I had invested not only in my PS3 which I specifically chose for GH, but several hundreds of dollars in the PS3 GH series, because I simply enjoy it. I'm not great at it, but it makes a tough day at work melt away.

What we (and I can't speak for all of us) gamers are upset about, is the lack of a simple timeframe when PSN will be back on. Really folks, that simple. Of course credit card fraud potential is paramount. To many of us, that is not the chief concern, we buy the PS3 cards or use pre-purchased cards to buy what we want...seriously if you use your main bank account card for PS3 or Xbox game time/store, etc...shame on you. I honestly wish more companies would get their act together and use PayPal...an exceptional service.

I work in the field of Safety/Risk Management. It is beyond my comprehension, that a company the size of Sony, a global Fortune 100 firm, did not have a plan in-place, and ready to execute. There's this thing many companies call a business continuity plan, or business contingency plan. I'm thinking that surely at least one of the talented people at Sony has brought this up as a concern at some point. I'd be willing to bet that at least one intelligent network designer has previously informed management, if this happens, we may have a problem. Many times such people are frowned upon by management, even told to "play ball" or else...work elsewhere's. I'm curious...just saying. I only know this because I've been in that position in the pharmaceutical business no less. They found a way to fire me with only 43-days to qualify for a pension. I'll live, my conscience is clean.

So, D-Day came and Sony was caught with their pants down. I've always been a student (albeit amateur) of Asian culture. Let me tell you all, when the three executives bowed their heads before the world...it was the most sincere gesture a Japanese executive could have possibly made. But, to most of the world, we just want a date. I saw an article someone mentioned this will not impact Sony financially much...probably from someone who owns Sony stock, or even worse, some broker's puppet. Granted it's only a piece of the Sony pie; however, for guys like me...I invest for the long term. Apologies aside, communications by Sony has been below par. Say what you will, but Microsoft is the dominant OS on this planet and they are not in this situation. Give us a date Sony and keep it, or please or face up to the longer term alternative.
Murdoch owned WSJ site secure? In the next world, maybe.
Why is everyone white and blonde?  Typical...

Excellent comment!

Herman in Houston wrote "the notion that this app makes reading an "interactive" and "emotional" experience is absurd." It's true that great books don't need anything other than words to communicate. But Al Gore hasn't written a novel. This is an educational non-fiction book that tries to describe a complex environmental problem and the technologies that can be used to address it. In cases like this, sometimes a video or an animated graphic can communicate a process much more clearly and efficiently than text can.

The approach used to create the Our Choice app will be incredibly effective for helping people understand topics such as geology (animations of glaciers receding and leaving behind the geological formations we see on the landscape today such as moraines, eskers, drumlins, etc.), human physiology, chemistry, physics, and even computer software manuals. In fact while reading Our Choice I started thinking what a great model it could be for learning how to use a computer, or to learn how to use software.

But for novels, give me an old-fashioned hardcover book anytime.

I wish people would drop the canard of Al Gore claiming to have invented the internet. He may have claimed credit for CREATING the internet, much like the Eisenhower administration is credited with creating the Interstate highway system.  Of course, Gore is not a computer engineer, and Eisenhower was not a road engineer. But we give leaders credit for "creating" things when their leadership opens up possibilities.

Joining the crowd requesting this format be used for Text Books.

And joining Frank from GA asking why did you title this article about Al Gore? Just added unnecessary debate.
Would love to experience this -- on a NON-Apple device, please.

I always enjoy your posts, Mr. Pogue, but you (and most other journalists) disappoint me when you refer to private citizens as "Mr. Vice President" or "Mr. President" after they have left office. In the United States, there are no titles of nobility and former political office holders are just that: former.
All you had to do is mention an endorsement from Al Gore and you've lost me as a future customer!.  I really thought I wanted an I-Pad, too

He doesnot care about the environment-he cares about Al Gore & making money.
Apple , too bad you're promoting him. I'm an apple user. I'll skip it.
I would not buy anything connected to Al Gore !
Thanks for the name dropping.

Members of the CUNY Board of Trustees are out of control, and this is just the latest example of their assault on academic standards and freedom, on the democratic process, and on civil discourse. Not one Board member had the moral courage to challenge the outrageous and slanderous comments made by a radical, self-focused, self-absorbed, political hack; and the Chancellor (as usual) stood by and said nothing. I'm embarrassed for the students, faculty (both full-time and contingent), and hard-working staff of CUNY. We deserve better than this, and we should all call on a Vote of No Confidence on this current bunch of Board members (and many of the expensive administrators they have endorsed and we have had to endure). Members of the CUNY Board of Trustees have violated the public trust, have abrogated their responsibilty to act as trustees, to protect the institution.

Rather than protect the institution and the students who spend their hard-earned money to receive an education, the current members of the CUNY Board of Trustees have consistently undermined academic freedom at every campus. They have consistently put their own selfish economic interests and political agendas, above the needs of our students and the City's most vulnerable. Indeed, they have preyed upon the vulnerable. Our Chancellor is also culpable, as today's editorial makes clear. And the Kushner business is only one of the many egregious acts committed by this Board, along with the Chancellor, their silent partner. They are currently attacking general education (and "selling" their latest assault on academic freedom as "helping" our students navigate their way through general education requirements). They clearly know nothing about education, or the by-laws that are supposed to guide their decisions. Knowledge, trust--these things seem to matter very little to the member sof CUNY's Board of Trustees.

For neglecting their fiduciary responsibility, and moral obligation, to the public we all serve, for abrogating their duty to uphold the public trust, New Yorkers should demand the resignations of all current Board Members now serving as CUNY Trustees. It's the only way to save one of the nation's most important institutions of public higher education, one of the few that has long promised to serve the under-served, including first-generation, immigrant, working-class students. Shame on this shameful group. Our students deserve better--and we should demand that they receive a Board of Trustees and other senior administrators who will protect their future rather than demolish it.

a once great institution shows its shabby side, more likely its decline, with a weak and careless Board presided over by a failed Yale President and one politicking fool who places his personal vendettas before the well-being of the institution and a number indifferent trustees of little intellect and which follow like sheep their ignorant leadership.
